metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Internet of medical things (IoMT)-integrated biosensors for point-of-care testing of infectious diseases Internet of medical things (IoMT)-integrated biosensors for point-of-care testing of infectious 1 diseases 2 3

abstract.text: On global scale, the current situation of pandemic is symptomatic of increased incidences of 20 contagious diseases caused by pathogens. The faster spread of these diseases, in a moderately 21 short timeframe, is threatening the overall population wellbeing and conceivably the economy. 22 The inadequacy of conventional diagnostic tools in terms of time consuming and complex 23 laboratory-based diagnosis process is a major challenge to medical care. In present era, the 24 development of point-of-care testing (POCT) is in demand for fast detection of infectious diseases 25 along with "on-site" results that are helpful in timely and early action for better treatment. In 26 addition, POCT devices also play a crucial role in preventing the transmission of infectious diseases 27 by offering real-time testing and lab quality microbial diagnosis within minutes. Timely diagnosis 28 and further treatment optimization facilitate the containment of outbreaks of infectious diseases. 29 Presently, efforts are being made to support such POCT by the technological development in the 30 field of internet of medical things (IoMT). The IoMT offers wireless-based operation and 31 connectivity of POCT devices with health expert and medical centre. In this review, the recently 32 developed POC diagnostics integrated or future possibilities of integration with IoMT are discussed 33 with focus on emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases like malaria, dengue fever, influenza A 34 (H1N1), human papilloma virus (HPV), Ebola virus disease (EVD), Zika virus (ZIKV), and coronavirus 35 (COVID-19). The IoMT-assisted POCT systems are capable enough to fill the gap between 36 bioinformatics generation, big rapid analytics, and clinical validation. An optimized IoMT-assisted 37 POCT will be useful in understanding the diseases progression, treatment decision, and evaluation 38 of efficacy of prescribed therapy. 39 40 41 medical things, Point-of-care-testing. 42 43 44 45 46 47 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f

body_text.text: Typical disease biomarkers include aptamer, antibodies, whole pathogen (e.g., bacteria and 158 viruses), and the molecular agents (e.g., nucleic acids and proteins) from the infectious agents. 159 Readily available conventional methods like microscopy and culturing are well established and 160 considered effective diagnostic for infectious diseases (Srivastava et al., 2018) . However, these 161 approaches face various challenges during viral markers detection such as i) low sensitivity in 162 microscopy methods and ii) need of highly skilled personnel and techniques in cell culturing to 163 carry out the reliable tests. Moreover, these conventional diagnostics also require more time for 164 clinical interpretations due to cultivation and drug susceptibility testing. Further, molecular 165 methods have increased laboratories throughput due to their higher sensitivity and ability to 166 detect infections faster than the conventional approaches (Lee et al., 2015) . Among these 167 molecular methods, nucleic acid amplification (NAA) assays, enzyme linked immunosorbent assay 168 (ELISA), colorimetric assay and other advance biotechnological methods are becoming more 169 famous and are routinely conducted in many clinical microbiology laboratories. However, these 170 healthcare techniques have several limitations such as too expensive for routine clinical diagnosis, 171 time-consuming (in terms of several hours or days to complete), and labour-intensive. The 172 continuous evolution of automated diagnostic tools like proteome chips, microfluidic, colorimetric 173 assay, and other advance molecular methods allows diagnosis from laboratory to bedside and 174 even recommended by the world health organization (WHO) for use in emergency and remote 175 settings. The selection of an appropriate diagnostic technique relies on the several parameters like 176 sensitivity, selectivity, cost, required time for diagnosis, and availability of the diagnostic tools. The 177 rapid diagnostic procedures can help in more efficient management of transmission of infectious 178 disease in an economic and reliable manner. 7 well in a portable manner. Recent advancement in technology has facilitated development efforts 229 toward portable and wearable POCT frameworks. Uptake of versatile and wearable gadgets 230 (smartphones, drones, and Bluetooth) transformed the entire POC system. Smart electronic 231 devices also allow real-time communication between patient and the health experts that ensure 232 effective diagnostic performance for healthcare management even in resource-limited settings 233 (Jin et al., 2020) . These attributes make POC diagnostics ideal for use as a rapid diagnostic device 234 for infectious diseases (refer to Fig. 4 ) management via detecting a marker and monitoring viral 235 infection progression. 236 237 In case of inaccessibility due to lacking availability and affordability of commercial diagnostic tests, 238 POC tests can sufficiently be utilized according to the accessibility of patients, even at home. Such diagnostics. Resolution of cell-phone camera lens can be effectively used for optical microscopy, 270 flow cytometry, and other imaging readouts for better real-time results (Nayak et al., 2017) . 271 Bluetooth low energy (BLE) technology-equipped POCs manifest data connectivity up to few feet 272 such as non-invasive mouthguard biosensor for salivary glucose and fitness trackers, to 273 continuously monitor patient's physical activity and vital signs. (Christodouleas et al., 2018) . 274 Research efforts are directed towards development of smart fabrics having sensing capabilities to 275 record blood pressure, electrocardiogram, heart rate, and body temperature. In 2020, a huge 276 number of internet-connected devices are available in market like medical kiosks, fitness tracking 277 devices (wrist band, smart watches, shorts etc), clinical grade wearables (smart belts, chest strap), 278 remote patient monitoring devices, smart pills, and many more (Ding et al., 2019) . Several non- 279 invasive samples like sweat, saliva, faeces, tears, and breath could be used in eHealth diagnostic 280 devices (eDiagnostics) to detect biomarkers of major diseases (viral infections, cancer, and HIV); 281 however, these devices are still in developing phase as the pathological level of these biomarkers 282 yet not established. At eHealth systems, several diagnostic needs could be covered by eDiagnostic 283 wearable devices. Interestingly, smartphones ubiquity is widely adopted among modest and low- 284 income peoples, promoting the use of POCT without additional costs. It will also increase medical 285 facilities in remote areas and rural communities at lesser costs. 286 287 Major motivation leading to rapid adoption of smartphone-based computing devices in health 288 system is the need of better communication, information resources, and social networking at the 289 POC (Lee Ventola, 2014) . Web browser gives interface for sending and receiving health 290 information with no time delay. In addition, IoMT device also offers other advantageous features, 291 like short message service, e-mail, global positioning systems (GPS), and interactive voice 292 recordings that can help towards automation of POC diagnostics in data collection and further 293 continuous transmission into a central database through satellite networks (Nayak et al., 2017 Meagher & group employed smartphone-based device for high performance diagnostics. They for infectious diseases need sample collection and preparation that limit biosensors capability 1159 from qualifying as POCT. Besides, reagents sometimes need refrigeration for long shelf-life forms 1160 that is another barrier for POC testing. Therefore, researchers start utilizing microfluidic platforms 1161 that carry out all the required operational step but, in a cost-prohibitive bulky setup. protocols and health data, and bioinformatics has emerged as a very serious concern. To secure 1261 the healthcare system from vulnerability exploitation, several options have been explored, e.g., 1262 blockchain-based IoT environment (Moin et al., 2019) . 1263 Expected economic revenues from capital investment in the designing, production, and marketing 1264 of novel POC for use in tropical developing countries are unattractive. Mostly, governmental 1265 organizations have financially supported commercial endeavors and research organization 1266 working on novel biosensor point of care technologies. Additional efforts for wider promotion of 1267 rapid diagnostic tests are expected from international public health organizations. Therefore, it is 1268 much more challenging to deal with barriers and develop a market for POCT assay supported by AI 1269 and IoMT (Fig. 16) In the coming years, widespread advancement of these bioanalytic tools is 1270 expected. This will ultimately be revolutionizing the world of clinical diagnostics to ease the 1271 disease burden in remote areas and even low-income countries. Synergetic approaches involving IoMT and POCT based biosensing system is an interdisciplinary 1280 research that cover wide expertise of various fields to offer benefits to a wide range of 1281 communities including microbiology, immunology, pathology, clinical biology, electronics, material 1282 chemistry, and other applied field of sciences. Presently, the research efforts are focused on 1283 exploration of novel and smart biosensing technology using novel nano-systems, bio-actives, 1284 computational analytics, and hardware integration to achieve easy operation and performance 1285 assessment that are required for timely therapy decision. Therefore, this article served as an 1286 appeal to a wide range of stakeholders including scientists, clinical practitioners, engineers, 1287 medical professionals, industrialists, educators, and students devoted to the development of 1288 affordable IoMT-assisted POCT biosensing system for intelligent healthcare to serve the humanity 1289 in a better way.

In summary, wide accessibility, real-time screening, specificity, and data computation in POC 1292 devices pave the way for prompt diagnosis of infectious diseases. POC helps effective patient-1293 centric treatment and management during pandemics. Although numerous challenges still 1294 associated with the POCT testing, the rapid advancements hold a huge potential for 1295 implementation of POCT programs to prevent the spread of infectious diseases. Currently 1296 technological research inclined most towards the next generation standalone POCT devices. 1297 Several smart applications are already commercialized for screening the basic health parameters, 1298 such as blood glucose, blood pressure, weight, and many more. Security and privacy are major 1299 concern for establishing the market of these POCTs. The global efforts will effectively tackle these 1300 challenges in the coming years. The framework, proposed in this article, can help in shaping many 1301 of the ongoing efforts to develop POC tests for pandemics.

The outbreak of 149 infectious disease sometimes remains undiagnosed for a period that allowed unseen transmission 150 of the virus, leading to large epidemics. Therefore, clinical awareness and the relevant knowledge 151 about diagnostic tools are critically important to perform as effective detectors and first-line 152 responders. Most importantly, in the fight against emerging infections, early and accurate 153 diagnosis is the most effective way to break the chain of transmission and mitigate the impact of 154 these diseases. In contrast, 1146 microfluidics and biosensor based POC diagnostic are still under development, facing challenges in 1147 terms of both implementation and interpretation along with clinical validations. In this era of 1148 pandemics, POCT devices will significantly contribute towards economics due to robust and low-1149 cost diagnosis (Ahmad et al., 2020). POC biosensors are portable devices hence can be available in 1150 remote locations and resource-limited settings. Moreover, early detection of infectious diseases 1151 benefits the government in controlling the outbreak. Rapid and accurate testing contributes 1152 significantly to epidemiologic studies and surveillance to estimate health status and future 1153 outbreaks of such infectious diseases. 1154 1155 However, development and commercialization of advanced biosensor technology is a bigger 1156 challenge considering its technical aspects (Everitt et al., 2020). Several factors work together in 1157 preventing translation of academic research to commercially viable devices. Primarily, biosensors 1158

These layouts need much 1200 improvement in terms of sensitivity and cross reactivity, hence are under continuous research to 1201 accomplish the needs for high-throughput analysis. Rapid multiplexing diagnostics are of 1202 significant use, particularly in cases of co-infections. However, several questions remain 1203 unresolved in case of these multiplexed biosensing devices such as proper evaluation, device has been established for diagnostics application, a timely validation of such 1207 system based on standard and FDA approved protocols is always recommended for better public 1208 usage and clinical application. Clinical accuracy is one of major challenges in front of these IoMT-1209 integrated POC systems due to lack of understanding of quality control as well as quality assurance practices related mainly with IoMT (Shaw, 2016). To ensure the accuracy of results, the 1211 implementation of quality assurance program is essential in POCT. Thus, it requires the 1212 establishments of standards with help of government, institutions, and experts. Usually most of 1213 the academic development fails on the part of patients and only few qualifies the first evaluation 1214 stage (McRae et al., 2020). This is mainly because of discrepancy between perception and reality 1215 as laboratory testing are carried out indoors rather than in the health care settings. Researchers 1216 are working on to address these drawbacks and developing new diagnostic tools via wide range of 1217 unprecedented opportunities in diagnostic biomarkers, detections methodology, and advanced 1218 nanomaterials (Califf, 2018). Moreover, computer-aided diagnosis systems or IoMT requires 1219 integration of big data analysis where different tools need to be explored like visualization tools, 1220 ML, and data mining. Data transmission and processing device play a major role in eHealth 1221 diagnostics, involving several challenges in terms of monitoring of patient's activities and health 1222 (Vitabile et al., 2019). In comparison to analogue approaches, computer-based or digital tools are 1223 more efficient and usually preferred by physicians. Beyond these technical challenges, clinical 1224 barriers also limit their performance. The main challenge is suitable disease biomarker that 1225 typically enable early diagnosis using simplified matrices in addition to allow testing at low level. 1226 Novel clinically relevant biomarkers from the advanced genomics and proteomics technique can 1227 be used to increase diagnostic accuracy. Predictive biomarkers facilitate early diagnosis as it can 1228 help identify individuals in early stages of diseases. Moreover, biomarker that can be detected in a 1229 non-invasive specimen is preferred for real time POCT devices. Hence, diagnostic biomarkers 1230 development together with sensing technology are reshaping diagnostic and therapeutic sciences 1231 as it prioritizes the quality and reproducibility of the POCT. Kumar et al., 2018a, 2018b; Nehra et al., 2019; 1242 Samaddar et al., 2018). Predictably, such uniform fabrication will be useful to develop a sensing 1243 device of desired features wherein reproducibility and reliability considered as keys. 1244 1245 Presently, efforts are being made to support such POCT by the technological development 1246 investigated in the field of IoMT to achieve wireless based operation and connectivity with health 1247 expert and medical centre (Sadoughi et al., 2020). These IoMT devices are a viable alternative to 1248 bulky and expensive laboratory systems. An optimized IoMT-assisted POCT will be useful to manage a targeted 1252 infectious disease via understanding diseases progression, decide treatment, and evaluate efficacy 1253 of prescribed therapy. POC devices must fulfil all the standard evaluation criteria put forth by the 1254 WHO using the acronym ASSURED-affordable, sensitive, specific, user friendly, rapid and robust, 1255 equipment-free, and deliverable to those in need (Everitt et al., 2020).
